rows.headline: The artist Oliver Jeffers sets his scale models against the universe of Manhattan.
rows.description: The Moon will be on 15th Street, and the Earth will be on 16th  Street, starting on Jan. 24, in a new public installation created by the artist Oliver Jeffers in partnership with the High Line.

rows.headline: It’s not that residents don’t like trees, a recent study found. They just don’t quite trust the city to take care of them.
rows.description: Deborah Westbrook, a lifelong resident of Detroit, would love a tree in front of her home.

rows.headline: Learn more about Californian wines and cheeses at a talk at the 92nd Street Y.
rows.description: Several of California’s most notable cheeses, including Vella Dry Jack and Cypress Grove Lamb Chopper will be served at the 92nd Street Y alongside powerful cabernet sauvignons and zinfandels from Napa and Sonoma Counties. The occasion is a talk by Martin Johnson, a cheese expert, and Michael Whidden, a wine distributor. They’ll explain the state’s big wines and big cheeses.

rows.headline: Francis warned against a resurgence of populist movements and urged compassion for migrants fleeing poverty, violence and natural disasters.
rows.description: ROME — Pope Francis defended “modern multilateral diplomacy” and international institutions against “the resurgence of nationalistic tendencies” in an address at the Vatican on Monday.

rows.headline: Jason B. Dalton pleaded guilty to murder in the shootings around Kalamazoo, Mich., in 2016. The attacks occurred between rides Mr. Dalton gave Uber passengers.
rows.description: A Michigan Uber driver accused of killing six people and wounding two others in a 2016 shooting spree pleaded guilty to murder on Monday just before his trial was set to begin.

rows.headline: Ms. Brown, 30, who as a teenage trafficking victim killed a man who had picked her up for sex, will be released in August after serving 15 years in prison.
rows.description: Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee granted clemency on Monday to Cyntoia Brown, commuting her life sentence for killing a man who had picked her up for sex when she was a teenage trafficking victim.

rows.headline: Philip Greene, a drinks historian and Marine official, stylishly straddles two different worlds in Washington.
rows.description: WASHINGTON — It was the perfect Philip Greene anecdote, equal parts military and mixology.

rows.headline: Our columnist offers some thoughts on topics that should remain of interest in 2019.
rows.description: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

rows.headline: A physical altercation on New Year’s Eve in the northern Iraqi city of Erbil left a Lockheed Martin contractor dead and three troops under investigation.
rows.description: WASHINGTON — Two Marines and a Navy corpsman stationed in northern Iraq are being investigated in the death of an American civilian contractor last week, two Defense Department officials said on Monday.

rows.headline: Taking the oath as California’s new governor, Gavin Newsom signaled a break from his predecessor, Jerry Brown, with a focus on income disparity.
rows.description: SACRAMENTO — Gavin Newsom was sworn in Monday as the 40th governor of California, ending the era of Jerry Brown with a broad promise of a more aggressive government that would turn its attention to the sharp economic disparities that have plagued this state.

rows.headline: A state court decision to vacate Michael C. Skakel’s conviction for the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley will stand, potentially signaling the end of a long legal battle.
rows.description: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

rows.headline: Expecting an indictment on corruption charges, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu went on television to attack the prosecutors investigating him as a ‘joke’ and ‘absurdity.’
rows.description: JERUSALEM — The announcement set Israel abuzz with suspense late Monday afternoon: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had a “dramatic statement” to deliver at 8 p.m., at the start of the most heavily watched news hour.

rows.headline: Apple’s declining sales reveal how important the health of China’s consumer market is to the world’s economy.
rows.description: In a rare bit of bad news for its investors, Apple last week laid the blame for lower than expected revenue on its performance in China. The news sent Apple’s stock price plunging, and investors also ditched other companies with significant exposure in China. The scale of the damage, both to Apple’s bottom line and to the broader market, underscores how critically important China — and Chinese consumers — have become for American companies.

rows.headline: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo appeared with Hillary Clinton to promise to strengthen reproductive rights within 30 days of the new legislative session.
rows.description: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

rows.headline: What happens when friends and allies can’t take the commander in chief at his word?
rows.description: President Trump and his administration have always had a mixed-messaging problem. Whether it had to do with the future of NATO, relations with the European Union, a rapprochement with Russia or a trade war with China, Mr. Trump has made norm-shattering pronouncements while his top advisers worked behind the scenes to preserve the status quo.

rows.headline: In Florida’s deeply conservative Panhandle, federal prison workers were already struggling after Hurricane Michael. Then came the government shutdown.
rows.description: MARIANNA, Fla. — A federal prison here in Florida’s rural Panhandle lost much of its roof and fence during Hurricane Michael in October, forcing hundreds of inmates to relocate to a facility in Yazoo City, Miss., more than 400 miles away.

rows.headline: President Trump rained cruelties on immigrants and asylum seekers and now wants hundreds of millions of dollars to address the humanitarian crisis he caused.
rows.description: As the government shutdown over President Trump’s demand for border-wall funding moves through week three, the administration is looking to cut a deal with Democrats by emphasizing the deepening humanitarian crisis at the border — a crisis caused in large part by this administration’s inhumane policies, political grandstanding and managerial incompetence.

rows.headline: Most of the witness at the drug conspiracy trial have come from the cartel’s managerial class. Edgar Galvan testified about what it was like to work in the lower echelons of the cartel.
rows.description: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

rows.headline: The government accused the International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala of interfering in its domestic affairs, and gave prosecutors 24 hours to leave.
rows.description: MEXICO CITY — The Guatemalan government said Monday that it would expel a United Nations-backed anticorruption panel, giving its prosecutors a day to leave the country in the most decisive effort yet by President Jimmy Morales to remove the body that has been investigating him and other top politicians.

rows.headline: State officials said Scott Raymond Dozier died in his prison cell, ending one of the most significant and bizarre death penalty cases in recent years.
rows.description: Unlike most death row inmates, Scott Raymond Dozier wanted to die.
